reviewText: Waste of time
The last time I was this pissed off at the end of a movie was X-Men: The Last Stand (3).

Assuming this was just going to be a reimagining of the 1985 Kiwi film The Quiet Earth (based on a 1981 science fiction novel of the same name), I was relieved to discover that Z for Zachariah isn't rehashing The Quiet Earth but is instead based on an even older book (you guessed it: Z for Zachariah, 1974). Similar to the recent movie Air, Zachariah is another case study of 2 or 3 individuals and what it means to be alone in the world versus *almost* alone in the world. The acting in Zachariah is remarkable, which is of paramount importance in a character-driven film. A simple plot is suitable; there was no reason to go beyond the profound meanings of being the only people alive. The soundtrack is perfect, adding icing to an already tasty cake. Like The Quiet Earth (TQE), Zachariah is a "last remaining boy meets last remaining girl" story complicated by a "wait, there's actually another boy too" scenario. Although a cerebral movie, Z for Zachariah pushes a restrained but hardly unbroken tension for its duration. In ways, this existential uncertainty is as impactful as something like The Walking Dead, with a different but no less potent sense of urgency since changes in group dynamics are greater in magnitude when fewer characters are alive. Both Z for Zachariah and Z for Zombies (The Walking Dead) bring up the finer points of "cooperate or die," but in Zachariah the common enemy element is absent (no zombies to contend with, just avoid radiation and you're all set), so the focus is completely on how the human race might continue in an arbitrary tribe of 3. If you want closure, watch Air instead, or even TQE (come to think of it, watch TQE no matter what). If you simply want a thought-provoking 95 minutes with an earnest and engaging story, then give Z for Zachariah a chance.

A slow-burning, intimate look at the tension between instinct and ethics in an apocalyptic landscape. Wrapped up in this "love & survival triangle" are serious questions such as What is sacred? What is worth sacrificing? Do morals matter in the face of death/extinction?

I enjoyed the performances of all three actors, but Chiwetel Ejiofor's character definitely stands out from the others as being the most nuanced. As a viewer you sympathize and dislike him in turns, and by the end you are left with a perfect ambivalent mixture of both sentiments. Such complexity may in fact be what has caused other reviews here to incorrectly deem the movie "racist". And while such an interpretation is so far from the truth it's almost laughable, I suppose if you are the type of person who prefers PoC to only play insipid and uninteresting characters, you can consider this your trigger warning and know that this film is -not- for you.

Supposedly, the movie is set in what is probably West Virginia after a nuclear incident.  There the unanswered questions and inconsistencies begin.

Anne (Australian Margot Robbie) lives with her dog on her family farm.  She sounds like she is always about to lose her voice.

Loomis (African Brit Chiwetel Ejiofor) shows up one day in an improvised spacesuit dragging what looks like a dumpster that's been converted into a type of camper.  He seems a bit touched.  Loomis had been a mile underground in some U.S. government bunker for scientists and politicians.  Why Loomis left that bunkers is never really explained.

Caleb (Chris Pine, the only American) later shows up.  Caleb is handsome and charming, instantly a threat to Loomis and of interest to Anne.  Caleb was working in a coal mine 50 miles away and has only just come above ground.

Loomis decides to build a waterwheel to generate electricity, but he insists he has to use the wood from the chapel Anne's father built.  Loomis needs Caleb's and Anne's help with this project.

Now the inconsistencies.  These three "Americans" hold their eating utensils like Europeans.  Caleb and Anne supposedly only lived 50 miles from each other, but she has a thick accent and he doesn't.

Anne's parents left her alone on the farm with 13 years old brother so they could go look for survivors.  Huh?  Then her brother left in search for their parents leaving her alone with the dog.  After Caleb shows up the dog seems to disappear.

None of them talk much about what happened.  No one asks why.  All very strange.

But there was this valley that was somewhat uneffected and a woman and two men were able to survive and make their life in this setting bearable. That weakening and the ending were the changes which I disliked -- much preferred how it played out in the novel. There is not a lot of action in the movie (or the book), and a good deal of the background is left to inference.

The title f the novel comes from a reference to a Bible ABC book. In the novel, there is an inner monologue towards the beginning where Ann contemplates that if Adam is the first man on earth, Zachariah should be the last. (That's one of the things that stuck with me from the novel.) This is alluded to in the movie once with a shot of the book and the page about Adam. Without that context, the title probably seems very random. Other pieces that stayed with me and seemed consistent:
-the gas station scene
-why the valley was protected
-the suit (though I keep conflating Loomis's gadgetry with Jeebee's from Wolf and Iron)

I very much wanted to like this movie. There is so much potential for the story and characters. Unfortunately, it does not deliver anything but an incredibly slow pace and unanswered questions. Who is Zachariah? What caused the holocaust? What happened to Caleb? Are there other survivors? What happened to the dog? Do they survive the following winter? Equally disappointing is character development which is weak and confused. For example, Chiwetel Ejiofor's character (John Loomis) who survived more than a year with his "safe suit" and Geiger counter ignores both and jumps into a radioactive pond. How could he be so stupid? Character driven drama is as lifeless as most of the planet because it appears the director couldn't make up his mind where he wanted to go. Instead, he teases the audience with the beginnings of several possible storylines none of which get finished. You have to decide for yourself what happens. Also, the relationship between Loomis and Margot Robbie's character is never clear enough for the arrival of Caleb (Chris Pine) to inject anything into the mix. This is a pointless and boring story that ends before it develops into anything. My copy of this is now in the trash.

Z is a novel by Robert C. O'Brien (pen name of Robert Leslie Conly) that was published posthumously in 1974.
The novel and movie are passed off as original, but in fact the 1959 movie "The World, The Flesh & The Devil" starring Harry Belafonte, Inger Stevens & Mel Ferrer is almost the same thing, only better, IMHO, although I do like the modern cinematic update of this previously told story.
I don't understand why the author never gave the original any credit (although in his defense, he did pass away before it was completed) but the movie producers of this "remake" could have given the original a nod, but I guess they didn't want to spend any money in acknowledgements.
The cast of both productions perform above average in their respective roles. I think the original is required viewing for anyone interested in this version, or this genre in general. Most people in the 21st century accept mixed race relations, but it was a brave groundbreaking movie for 1959.

Film buffs will want to watch this very well done drama set in a post nuclear war world.  At least we think it is post war.  What we know for sure is that almost everyone on earth is dead and that radiation continues to be dangerous.  But enough said about that.  The film's charm comes from the delicate acting of the three people in the film and the tension built up by the careful direction by Craig Zobel, a new director that grandly displays his chops here.
  Australian beauty Margot Robbie continues her career as a movie star with this measured role.  We know she is an actress as well as a star and this film confirms it.  Chris Pine and Chiwetel Cjiofor play two other survivors who vie for what for all they know is the last woman on earth.  Cjiofor plays a scientist who woos too  while Pine plays a coal miner, a younger, more vigorous and more aggressive man.  What plays out amounts to a dread filled drama about a love triangle.
  Or is it something else entirely.  Is the scientist a man of such complete self control that he can plan his moves so far ahead that none of the others even know that there is a game about?  We don't know, even after the film is over.  And isn't it a compliment to a film maker that after the show we can continue to talk about the film and speculate?
  Some people found this to be too slow moving but I found it careful, thoughtful and very carefully constructed.  We dip into male-female stuff at a very deep level and also touch on religion and even race-which still has an import even when the world population is reduced to three.

It's a good thing that there weren't three people in the Garden of Eden, or else none of us might be around today. Love triangles seem to have been around since the time of the Garden, but the one in "Z for Zachariah" takes on special significance, since the two men competing for the affection of the same woman in this post-nuclear apocalyptic tale may very well be the last three people alive on Earth.

"Z for Zachariah" is based on a 1970's YA novel by Robert O'Brien, but the film differs significantly from the book (which only had two characters) and, in fact, seems more like a loose remake of a significantly better 1950's film that covered the same general subject matter, "The World, the Flesh and the Devil." In the current movie, the world has supposedly been decimated by a nuclear holocaust, but all viewers get to see in "Zachariah"'s 95 minutes is an incredibly idyllic, rustic Appalachian valley that's somehow immune to the radiation. Ann Burden (Margot Robbie) has lived on a farm in that valley her entire life and still runs the farm well enough to keep herself fed. Her solitary existence is disrupted by the arrival of two strangers, first an engineer, John Loomis (Chiwetel Ejiofor,) and, later, a miner, Caleb (Chris Pine), both of whom had been underground since the catastrophe. Although the three try to act civilized about the entire matter, both men wind up vying for Ann's attention.

For an end-of-the-world film, Zachariah is surprisingly low key. There are no mutants or zombies or ruthless mobs of skinhead warriors running around; in fact, other than some high radiation readings in an early scene in which Loomis accidentally bathes in a contaminated spring, no signs of anything other than a near bucolic paradise. And thats part of the problem. Everything, including the actors, who have movie-star looks (Robbie tries to look a bit plain but never manages it), just looks far too good to have been through a nuclear disaster. In The World, the Flesh, and the Devil, the deserted streets of New York City were a constant reminder that something was very wrong; here, everything looks very right.

Beneath this idyllic surface, however, director Craig Zobel and the actors create some intriguing conflicts. In addition to the obvious sexual tension, and the equally obvious racial tension (which is there, but less of a concern to the characters than it was in the original), there is the tension based on age, as the clearly older Loomis worries and wonders if Ann will find the younger Caleb a better catch. And there is the age-old tension about science and religion. The devout (and virginal) Ann has been rather accepting of what has happened, but Loomis, a scientist, is more concerned about the long term and has ideas for restoring power that involve a major sacrifice on Anns part.

These tensions are all on display, although rarely openly. The script has minimal dialogue, and the pace of the movie is quite slow, so its left to the actors to carry the weight. Fortunately, all three are up to the task, especially Ejiofor, who has the most complex role. Still, despite the performances, the film often seems to drag, as Zobel is preoccupied with scenes such as a lengthy montage about the construction of a waterwheel for power. The films ending, however, is quite a stunner, especially for its abruptness, so much so that some viewers will want to replay it to be sure they didn't miss anything.

Overall, Z for Zachariah is decent entertainment, primarily for the actors performances and the relatively interesting premise. Yet it feels like a giant missed opportunity, less like any end-of-the-world film Ive ever seen and more like a threesome in paradise dating reality show. Im giving the film a marginal recommendation, but viewers really interested in this films concept should check out the superior The World, the Flesh and the Devil..

Here's a melodrama that could play out on stage with no more set than a piece of rope and a bathroom basin -- those two props are the pivotal moments in a tragedy of greed and lust with the superfluous context of a world in ruins and radioactive contamination.  Numerous elements of the story are put in place and go unused and ignored -- this is not a technically sophisticated story, it's not a deeply researched examination, it's not a study in psychology (though it purports to start out on each of those, only to seemingly forget it started the sentence) and it ends without ever framing a real question or delivering the satisfaction of an answer.
I think this is a story that deserves a better rendition in film, less style, fewer millions in the paychecks, more minutes of the screen time invested in the characters, less in the time-wasting of a tractor plowing a field -- how more straightforward and literal can you get than the time-wasting of a tractor plowing a field?
The writing excels in moving the pieces of the characters' personalities in and out of trust, in and out of trial by ordeal, in and out of the connections and conflicts of life.  The story seems powerful, but feebly done in this movie.  A pity.  I  think the story showed real potential.
The actors are accomplished and skilled but this movie does not exhibit their abilities; type cast, they are not, those the beauty of the leading woman is unmistakable, yet the director chose to gratuitously undress her, and that mistake came early and misdirected expectations with tedious attempts at sexual tension.
By all means, play it one evening and expect to be entertained, if not wowed.  I look forward to the next work from all three actors, but somewhere in the team of people writing and filming this movie, a lot of very capable people in the movie industry put together a high powered yawner.

This was a great movie.  Although its never directly stated, it is inferred that a nationwide (perhaps worldwide) nuclear explosion has occurred.  I had to watch the film several times to grasp all the indoor footage since it is necessarily shadowy (only candle light - no electricity) or perhaps its the color adjustment on my TV.  At any rate, the setting is a farm in a beautiful valley in what I suspected was to represent rural Virginia.  The father, who never actually appears in the movie, is said to be the minister of the local country church, and it is inferred that his farm and the valley was spared from nuclear destruction by the grace of God.  Only a young Christian woman (the farmer's daughter - approx. age 18?) and her dog is left alone to run the farm while her remaining family members search for survivors.  At the opening of the movie, six months or so has passed without their return.  Eventually, a scientist emerges from an underground bunker in DC and braves the radioactivity to find the valley.  Then a (West Virginia?) coal miner, who also survived the tragedy by being underground, drifts into the area...the last three people on earth(?)  The very realistic problem solving of plowing and planting without tractor fuel as well as finding a source for electricity to operate the freezers for the winter food storage begins.  Then the predictable rivalry between the two men in an unspoken challenge over the girl arises.  The only unlikely problem I found was the girl's sudden behavioral change.  At the beginning, she is a proper, obedient Christian girl, very mature in her domestic responsibilities and all sweetness and light.  Suddenly, she does a 180 in her moral behavior, which I found impractical and confusing.  Frankly, I expected the men to be the ones making the sexual advancements.  But one minute shes devotedly playing religious music on the church organ, praying and defending her Christian faith, and then the next moment shes all but jumping in bed with the men.  However, I suppose being left all alone for six months or so with the assumption that your family will never return, and believing that you're only one of three humans left on the face of the earth would create a serious conflict in your mind.  In any case, it is a fast paced film, realistically thought out and that holds your interest all the way to the end.  Actually, I could envision a sequel as other survivors of the catastrophe slowly begin to emerge from shelters and find their way into the valley, something along the lines of the Walking Dead.

If you're going to make a love story, the best way to go about it is to do something differently from the norm.  Then again Z For Zachariah isn't quite a true love story anyway since the film seems to be about two men quietly trying to win over the same girl, so the actual romance doesn't occur that often.  This is a *very* quiet and slow-moving storyline, but it's effective enough that I enjoyed it.

An apocalypse happens.  At first we're led to believe Margot Robbie (who's VERY cute by the way- sorry just had to get that in there!) is all alone with her dog and stranded on her farm.  Then while walking along the hilltops she sees a vehicle in the middle of the road with nobody around.  She gets nervous since she thinks she's the only survivor on the planet.  Normal behavior.  Chiwetel Ejiofor appears, and luckily for Margot he's here to contribute realizing the two need to stick together to survive (well not at first... not when Margot pulls a gun on Chiwetel who's only trying to enjoy a nice swim!)

Chiwetel is a handyman and in my opinion the best actor in the movie.  He can build a windmill powered by electricity (hydroelectricity that is).  He can run generations to make sure everything around the house is running.  He knows how to get gas to squirt from pumps at nearby gas stations without the need for electricity.  He can help with the farming in the fields.  Chiwetel and Margot become more than just good friends and survivors- they start developing feelings for each other.  However halfway through the movie Chris Pine comes along.  He doesn't seem as trustworthy as Chiwetel.  Though he comes off as perfectly normal, you get the feeling something is off and he's hiding something.

Margot seems attracted to Chris more so than Chiwetel, but to be honest the feeling I got while watching this story develop is that she's only casually interested in either.  She second guesses her sexual decisions with both (such as removing her clothing while sitting on bed for Chiwetel, or how she reluctantly approaches the bathroom where Chris is).  It's like Margot wants romance... but she doesn't want romance!  I won't spoil what happens later but uh, well I won't mention it.  Let's just say Chris comes off like a super nice guy but something happens to him.

It's not like the whole movie is based around romance.  There are elements of the three working together in the fields and especially working on that windmill that deviates from the love portion of the story.  I enjoy this movie but I can understand the complaints.  The movie feels like there should have been more to it.  More should have developed between all three characters.  More backstory (though we get just enough I think).  Perhaps more friction between Chiwetel and Chris should have occurred, leading to some actual fighting or suspenseful moments between the two (and the door was certainly open for such moments when the two went hunting together and it appeared Chris had a gun pointed at the back of Chiwetel's head).  I don't know.

But when a stranger Caleb (Chris Pine) enters the valley, their precarious bond begins to unravel into an emotionally charged love triangle as the last known survivors.

We wonder how landscape so beautiful and fertile in the scenes where the trio relates could be so perfect if indeed there has been a nuclear war that destroyed everyone on the planet. The cinematography is absolutely breathtaking. But the story's powerhouse center is comprised of brilliant, brilliant performances all around -- plus an ending that's haunting and heartbreaking on multiple levels. If you're looking for pulse-pounding, fast-paced action, this movie will NOT be your cup of tea ... and that's NOT the kind of movie it's trying to be. Four ENGAGING Stars. "Z for Zachariah" is a deliberately-paced, post-apocalyptic drama based on the eponymously-titled book by award-winning author Robert C. O'Brien. This is a psychodrama with no Sci-Fi action or CGI effects. Beautifully shot, the movie begins with a person in a strange outfit foraging in a completely empty, dilapidated town. When she finally strips away the plastic suit, away from the town and high in the hills, it is the character Ann who is apparently the last survivor of the nuclear war, living a very austere life, played wonderfully by Australian actress Margot Robbie ("The Wolf of Wall Street", "Focus") using a soft Southern accent. In the book, she is 18 and believes she is the last surviving human. Later, her dog finds a delirious man in a metallic suit, Loomis, played by Chiwetel Ejiofor ("12 Years A Slave", "The Martian"), another survivor who, surveying the area radiation levels, discovers this is a high-country paradise isolated from deadly nuclear radiation. They form a tenuous relationship, and when Chris Pine (Captain Kirk of the "Star Trek" movies and "Jack Ryan, Shadow Recruit") arrives, playing Caleb, the storyline is set: the last woman and the last two men on Earth, different philosophies, different pasts, different attractions, different needs, a common cause, all rushing towards an unexpected climax. The actors are brilliantly cast and the acting is fantastic.

Robert C. O'Brien did not finish the last part of the book before he passed: the book was completed by family based on his notes-it's possible we might have gotten both a different book and movie ending, had he finished it. I was excited to see they had made a movie of one of my favorite novels. I approached it almost with reverence, albeit with some trepidation that they might veer from the original subject matter. When I saw the promo picture, I knew something was amiss, for there were only two characters in the novel. I had hopes the damage was not too severe, but the moving and elegantly written novel was completely eviscerated, and there was little to enjoy, aside from the scenery, in this sad knockoff. That is not to say that the actors were not good in their roles, they acted their parts as given to them, but the screenplay had none of the grit, drama, or faith of the original. Anne's faith in God and her relationship with Him was trivialized and mocked, rather than being central to her strength and survival. John was not nearly as developed as he was in the novel, and became almost charming. His intent on furthering the human race at any cost was actually reversed, and Anne was subjected to none of the grief and adventure which were to result in the final catharsis of the novel. Not that that matters, that choice was never even made in the movie. All tragedies were averted, and nothing can be learned from the resultant saccharine and weak version we have been given. Heck, even her dog survived. Changing John's race and Anne's age were poor decisions that confused the relationship and interaction between these two characters, and adding Caleb distracted from and marred the beauty and intent of the original storyline. The adaptation was painful to watch, and I am looking forward to reading the novel again so that I might forget this inept fumbling of what had been great literature. It is a real travesty, as the original story was something to move the soul. Two thumbs down, and 0 stars if I could rate it so.

Potential spoilers.  It seems like there are 5 or 6 movies that surface each year dealing with life after an apocalyptic event.  Most are action/thrillers with good guys fighting off the bad guys or aliens.  Every once in a while, a quieter more serene film is released.  2012s "Die Wand (The Wall)" comes to mind.  This film is actually based on a 1975 young adult novel by Robert C. OBrien.  The storys heroine, Ann Burden believes she is the only survivor after what we are led to believe is the aftermath of World War III, or at least a nuclear holocaust.  In OBriens novel, Ann is 16 but here she appears to be about 19 and is played perfectly by a tomboyish Margot Robbie.  If your reference point for Ms. Robbie is her stunning turn in The Wolf of Wall Street or Focus you're in for a pleasant surprise.  Those early films were no fluke.  This girl can act.

Anns been on her own for a while living in a valley set in the high rolling hills of somewhere in the U. S.  She has no electricity, but grew up on a farm so has been self-sufficient.  Her only friend is her dog.  While out hunting, she comes upon a strange looking cart left in the middle of the road.  Exploring further she comes across a black man, bathing in a natural pond.  Fearful at first, her need for human contact provokes her to approach, screaming that the water is contaminated by radiation.  John Loomis (Chiwetel Ejiofor), an engineer who survived because he was deep underground during the event has been wearing a protective suit and has been seeking higher ground.  He becomes seriously ill but is cared for with medication he had in his cart and Anns nursing skills.

John learns quickly that Ann is a religious young woman, always referencing Him (God) and His plan.  Her father was a minister and she has numerous religiously themed books in her library.  One is a childrens book that John opens to the first chapter, A is for Adam which I suspect is where the film and books title comes from.  There is the occasional chafing between Anns faith and Johns science, but they both respect each others beliefs.

Stepping away from the novel, director Craig Zobel and screenwriter Nissar Modi introduce a new character halfway through the film.  Caleb  OK, sure  is played by hunky Chris Pine and brings an obvious third party conflict into the mix.  Earlier, given the opportunity by a wine-fortified Ann, John turned down Anns romantic advances.  Ann is clearly not experienced and portrays a certain naivety throughout the movie.  As John suggests to Ann, things change after sex.  Caleb and Ann have a spark as well.  But where will it go?  Re-populating the species is subtly suggested more than once.

For a while, the trio live in apparent harmony.  John and Caleb manage to build a power source (water wheel) to fuel a generator for electricity, but how long will this all last?  Those looking for action, thrills and chills need to look elsewhere.  The film languidly moves along and is based upon the interaction between the 3 characters.  The film is also open to metaphorical interpretation.  And if you need a tidy conclusion, this isn't your film.  I loved it.

In 2012, Craig Zobel's impressive but difficult to endure directorial debut Compliance looked with dim-colored glasses at the ways power can be used to control others. His follow-up, the sci-fi flavored Z for Zachariah also looks at authority, albeit a much higher one, and how one's faith can be manipulated by others to achieve their ends, but also how we use it to lie to ourselves about our own desires.

Only three characters occupy space in this intimate but gripping thriller set in the wake of a disaster that has destroyed the human population and rendered much of the planet uninhabitable.  Margot Robbie trades in the glamorous characters we're accustomed to seeing her in for the role of Ann, the lone survivor in a pocket of unaffected land. More than capable of surviving on her own, although her trusty dog is by her side, Ann hunts and farms to eke out a meager, lonely existence.  That changes when she encounters Loomis (Chiwetel Ejiofor), the first human she's seen in ages and a lifeline out of her despair. It's clear he's been in much the same boat, and after an accident leaves him sick with radiation poisoning the two set aside their mutual mistrust to take care of one another.

Anytime two lonely people are placed in such close proximity the spark of romance is probable, but it's inevitable given the extreme nature of their circumstances.  And while Zobel slowly builds to that passion through their work to build a sustainable life, he's more interested in the ideological differences that could derail everything.  She's driven by the power of her religious convictions, believing to the core of her being that God has done all of this for a reason. Loomis, while not an outright atheist, is a scientist who has no qualms about tearing down her father's old church to build a power source to survive a harsh winter. While there are no pointed, heated debates, the film is too elegantly constructed for that, its never far out of mind as new temptations creep into their lives. The arrival of a shady but charming drifter named Caleb (Chris Pine) awakens the passion in Ann, while also providing her an outlet to express her faith. Naturally it doesn't please Loomis to nearly the same degree, and soon the pressure builds between both men as they subtly one-up each other to win Ann's love.

Rich with themes of jealousy, contempt, and lust, Z for Zachariah explores the internal conflict between the needs of the flesh and of the soul. It's a powerful follow-up for Zobel, and he's proving to be a director capable of pulling the best from his actors. It's refreshing to see Robbie in a complicated, vanity-free role like this as she was already getting pigeonholed as a screen vixen. As Ann she gets to show vulnerability we've yet to see from her before, and at this point one has to recognize how integral she's been to the success of every film she's been in. Ejiofor is simply amazing once again, and perhaps has the most complicated, wide-ranging role to play. Once again Ejiofor is placed in the role of a man forced to endure hardships, both great and small, for a chance to live the life he imagined. Pine's role is less defined than the others but its good to see him outside of a larger ensemble for once.

While predicting which films will go on to greater things outside of the festival is always tricky, Z for Zachariah is a masterfully done film of deep complexity that everyone would be wise to seek out.

Despite its post-apocalyptic backdrop, Z for Zachariah is not a movie about the end of the world. Though the state of the human race is certainly a component, the film is more about the complexity of relationships (especially under unusual circumstances). In scope, this is not a huge movie. Its fairly contained, in fact, but the viewer slowly falls into this world thats been effortlessly created by director Craig Zobel.

The film opens with our main character Ann (Margot Robbie), a resourceful woman whos managed to stay alive and keep her farm productive in the face of a mysterious disaster thats left the planet desolate. Shes surviving and keeping a life for herself when she comes across another human being: a scientist ravaged mentally from radiation exposure (Chiwetel Ejiofor). She takes him in, managing to nurse him back to health, and they form a distinct bond. However, this connection quickly unravels when a stranger enters the picture (played by Chris Pine). A love triangle emerges amidst the complications of survival and starting over, and the performances between the three are truly accomplished.

The dynamic between these characters is something that has definitely been done before, but theres something refreshing about the simplicity of the film. At times, it feels as if it could be a play. There are very few elaborate settings, with a lot of the most important moments taking place at a dinner table or in front of an old chapel. Dialogue isn't necessary in many of these small moments. Things can be interpreted through body language and the expression on a characters face. Its a certain type of filmmaking that you don't see very often anymore, and I applaud Craig Zobel for his restraint and finesse. This is certainly one of the more thought-provoking movies Ive seen all year, and is definitely worth your time.

It's not that Z For Zachariah is bad for any particular stand-out reason - it's more than it's an amalgamation of things that don't work together. As such, it comes across as some sort of Lifetime drama you might watch in a hospital where pain-relieving drugs might fix the problems of the third act. It's a gentle snooze, pregnant with promise to explode into violence, but instead is satisfied with turning a church into a hydro-electric generator somewhere towards the end.

It needed some external force to nudge the main characters into action - either the threat of zombies (The Walking Dead), the end of the world's food supply (Interstellar) or the ticking timebomb of death (and watching Arnie trying to act) in Maggie. Instead, the cast is happy to eat, drink, farm, walking around slowly in radiation suits, and chat. And for readers of the original book who didn't see the trailer, Chris Pine's late arrival creates what is adventurously described as a "love triangle" which lets the movie coast into a finale that doesn't really resolve anything.

Ultimately the movie conversion removes the themes of the book and replaces them with Chris Pine and a waterwheel. It's so spectacularly uncinematic that you have to wonder how it got through the production process. In all fairness, the acting is fine and Margot Robbie is good, but there is less tension in the whole movie than in the opening credits of The Walking Dead. It's a little like ordering a pizza and the car shows up with a pack of cereal - it's probably better for you but you can't escape the disappointment.

Many of the bad reviews say the ending leaves too much to the imagination.  These are the same people still upset by Tom Hanks standing in that dirt road intersection at the end of Castaway fifteen years ago with a happy smirk on his face just before the screen went black. Ann Burden (Margot Robbie) and her dog have managed to survive the nuclear holocaust due to the topography of her land and using common sense in dealing with contamination. She meets up with John Loomis (Chiwetel Ejiofor) who has a Geiger counter and a type A protective suit on steroids. He suggests making a generator using hydro-electric power from the water falls. However, in order to do this he would have to take apart the church her father/preacher built. If you happen to look at the DVD cover or movie poster then you know Chris Pine also shows up and the description says "emotionally charged love triangle" which is a not exactly a plot spoiler, but he does come late into the film. If there was some way to watch the film having never seen the poster, or knowing he shows up, that would be the way to do it. As for me, I kept waiting for him to show up which made the film go slow with anticipation. So if you are planning a showing, hide the DVD cover.

The title comes from a kids book Ann has on the Bible. John opens the book and sees "A is for Adam." One would conclude what "Z" would be, as there is a hint and some talk that coating the world with radioactive contamination was part of the plan or at least Ann's survival. The book of Zachariah, talks about the rebuilding of Solomon's Temple as a juxtaposition to the discussing to tearing down the church. "Z For Zachariah" (2015 release; 95 min.) brings the story of a couple of survivors of an unidentified contamination or radiation. As the movie opens, we see someone with a protective mask going through an empty town to pick up various things, including books from the library. When later the person takes off the mask, we see it is a young woman, named Ann.  Ann and her dog live on their own, tending to the land and surviving as best they can. Then Ann runs into another survivor, a man named John. When John inadvertently takes a swim in a contaminated lake, he becomes very ill. Ann takes him home and nurtures him back to health. At this point we are 15 minutes into the movie, but to tell you much more of the plot would spoil your viewing experience, you'll just have to see for yourself how it all plays out.

Couple of comments: first, the movie's end titles say that the is "Based on the book by Robert O'Brien", but it would have been better to have said "very loosely based on/inspired by Robert O'Brian's book", as the plot for this film version differs dramatically and almost unrecognizably from the book. Since it is featured openly in the movie's trailer, besides Ann and John (the two characters in the book), the movie introduces a third character, Caleb. Second, while the setting of the movie is post-apocalyptic, the movie really doesn't feel all that much sci-fi. It's just three characters playing out their lives in an unspecified location somewhere in the US. In fact, the movie feels just as much being a Nicolas Sparks-like romantic drama than it is a sci-fi movie. Other elements featured in the movie include religion, and race. Third, the acting performances are strong. Up-and-coming Aussie actress Margo Robbie (also in The Wolf of Wall Street) does great work. She is definitely going places, that much is clear. Chiwetel Ejiofor and Chris Pine play John and Caleb, respectively. Fourth, the movie was mostly shot on location in New Zealand, with some additional shooting in West Virginia. Gorgeous sceneries most of the time. Last but certainly not least, there is a very nice orchestral score, composed by Heather "The Instruments" McIntosh.

I had been looking forward to seeing this movie, and it finally opened this weekend at my local art-house theater here in Cincinnati. The matinee screening where I saw this at was attended okay but not great. If you are in the mood for a romantic drama with a slight sci-fi twist, you'll definitely want to check this out. On the other hand, if you read and loved the book, you will absolutely want to avoid this.
